2 Probability

2.1 Sample Space

  • The set of all possible outcomes of an experiment.

2.2 Event

  • Subsets of the sample space.

2.3 Frequency

Run a random experiment nnn times, during which an event AAA occurs mmm times:

frequency of AAA's occurrence is $$f_A=\frac{m}{n}$$

2.4 Probability

a numerical description of how likely an event is to occur and or how likely that a proposition is true.

The probability of AAA occurs:

lim⁡n→+∞fA≡P(A)=p\lim_{n\to +\infin}f_A \equiv P(A)=p n→+∞lim​fA​≡P(A)=p

  • 0≤P(E)≤10\le P(E)\le 10≤P(E)≤1 for each even EEE;
  • P(S)=1P(S)=1P(S)=1;

If the events, A and B, are disjoint events(mutually exclusive), the probability that either event occurs is

P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B)  where  P(A∩B)=0P(A\cup B) = P(A)+P(B) \\ =P(A)+P(B)-P(A \cap B)\; \mathrm where\; P(A \cap B)=0 P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B)whereP(A∩B)=0

2.5 Conditional Probability

The probability of an event AAA given that an event BBB has occurred, is called the conditional probability of AAA given BBB and is denoted by the symbol P(A∣B)P(A|B)P(A∣B) and read as ‘the probability of AAA given that BBB has already occurred.

If AAA and BBB are two events with P(A)≠0P(A)\neq 0P(A)​=0 and P(B)≠0P(B)\neq 0P(B)​=0,then

P(A∣B)=P(A,B)P(B)    and    P(B∣A)=P(B,A)P(A)P(A|B)=\frac{P(A,B)}{P(B)}\;\; and\;\;P(B|A)=\frac{P(B,A)}{P(A)} P(A∣B)=P(B)P(A,B)​andP(B∣A)=P(A)P(B,A)​

The probability that both of the two events AAA and BBB occur is

P(A∩B)=P(A)⋅P(B∣A)=P(B)⋅P(A∣B)P(A\cap B) = P(A)\cdot P(B|A)= P(B)\cdot P(A|B) P(A∩B)=P(A)⋅P(B∣A)=P(B)⋅P(A∣B)

2.6 Law of Total Probability

Assume that B1,B2,...,BnB_1,B_2,...,B_nB1​,B2​,...,Bn​ are collectively exhaustive events where P(Bi)>0P(B_i)\gt 0P(Bi​)>0, for i=1,2,...,ni=1,2,...,ni=1,2,...,n and BiB_iBi​ and BjB_jBj​ are mutually exclusive events for i≠ji\neq ji​=j.
Then for any event AAA:

P(A)=P(B1,A)+P(B2,A)+...+P(Bn,A)P(A)=P(B_1, A)+P(B_2, A)+...+P(B_n, A) P(A)=P(B1​,A)+P(B2​,A)+...+P(Bn​,A)

=P(B1)P(A∣B1)+P(B2)P(A∣B2)+...+P(Bn)P(A∣Bn)=P(B_1)P(A|B_1)+P(B_2)P(A|B_2)+...+P(B_n)P(A|B_n) =P(B1​)P(A∣B1​)+P(B2​)P(A∣B2​)+...+P(Bn​)P(A∣Bn​)

2.7 Bayes’ Formula

Inverts the conditioning

Suppose that B1,B2,...,BnB_1,B_2,...,B_nB1​,B2​,...,Bn​ are n exhaustive events and exhaustive events, then:

P(Bk∣A)=P(Bk∩A)P(A)P(B_k|A)=\frac{P(B_k \cap A)}{P(A)} P(Bk​∣A)=P(A)P(Bk​∩A)​

=P(Bk)P(A∣Bk)P(B1)P(A∣B1)+P(B2)P(A∣B2)+...+P(Bn)P(A∣Bn)=\frac{P(B_k)P(A|B_k)}{P(B_1)P(A|B_1)+P(B_2)P(A|B_2)+...+P(B_n)P(A|B_n)} =P(B1​)P(A∣B1​)+P(B2​)P(A∣B2​)+...+P(Bn​)P(A∣Bn​)P(Bk​)P(A∣Bk​)​

$\because P(B_k\cap A) = P(B_k)\cdot P(A|B_k) \text{ :based on the Conditional Probability}$

$\text{,and }P(A)=P(B_1)P(A|B_1)+P(B_2)P(A|B_2)+…+P(B_n)P(A|B_n) $
based on the Law of Total probability\text{based on the Law of Total probability}based on the Law of Total probability

2.8 Independent Events

knowing FFF occurred doesn’t change the probability of EEE:

P(E,F)=P(E)P(F)P(E,F)=P(E)P(F) P(E,F)=P(E)P(F)

In this case:

∵P(E,F)=P(E)⋅P(F)∴P(E∣F)=P(E,F)P(F)=P(E)\because P(E, F)=P(E)\cdot P(F)\\ \therefore P(E|F)=\frac{P(E, F)}{P(F)}=P(E) ∵P(E,F)=P(E)⋅P(F)∴P(E∣F)=P(F)P(E,F)​=P(E)

2.10 Naïve Bayes classifier

Naive Bayes, Clearly Explained!!! - YouTube

Bayes’ Rule Applied to Documents and Classes (Multinomial Naive Bayes)

  • A generative and linear classifier.
  • Naive Bayes classifier has many assumptions including ignoring the words order and words are independent with each other, which makes it does not exhibit high accuracy.

ddd: document;
ccc: class;
To get the maximum value of P(c∣d),c∈CP(c|d),c \in CP(c∣d),c∈C, which means given the document ddd, find its class with the maximum probability.

The goal: to get the maximum value of

P(c∣d)=P(d∣c)P(c)P(d)P(c|d)=\frac{P(d|c)P(c)}{P(d)} P(c∣d)=P(d)P(d∣c)P(c)​

which is

cMAP=arg max⁡c∈CP(c∣d)c_{MAP}=\argmax_{c\in C}P(c|d) cMAP​=c∈Cargmax​P(c∣d)

MAPMAPMAP is maximum a posteriori = most likely class,

=arg max⁡c∈CP(d∣c)P(c)P(d)=\argmax_{c\in C}\frac{P(d|c)P(c)}{P(d)} =c∈Cargmax​P(d)P(d∣c)P(c)​

Bayes’ Formula,

=arg max⁡c∈CP(d∣c)P(c)=\argmax_{c\in C}P(d|c)P(c) =c∈Cargmax​P(d∣c)P(c)

where P(d)P(d)P(d) is not related to ccc,

=arg max⁡c∈CP(x1,x2,...,xn∣c)P(c)=\argmax_{c\in C}P(x_1,x_2,...,x_n|c)P(c) =c∈Cargmax​P(x1​,x2​,...,xn​∣c)P(c)

where ddd is represented with x1,x2,...,xnx_1,x_2,...,x_nx1​,x2​,...,xn​, e.g. words in an email,
and P(c)P(c)P(c) is the frequency of occurrence of this class, by count the relative frequencies, e.g. the frequencies of normal emails and spam emails,

Based on:

Bag of Words assumption: Assume position doesn’t matter;
Conditional Independence: Assume P(xj∣cj)P(x_j|c_j)P(xj​∣cj​) are independent;

then,

P(x1,x2,...,xn∣c)=P(x1∣c)⋅P(x2∣c)⋅...⋅P(xn∣c)=∏x∈XP(x∣c)P(x_1,x_2,...,x_n|c)=P(x_1|c) \cdot P(x_2|c) \cdot ... \cdot P(x_n|c)=\prod_{x\in X}P(x|c) P(x1​,x2​,...,xn​∣c)=P(x1​∣c)⋅P(x2​∣c)⋅...⋅P(xn​∣c)=x∈X∏​P(x∣c)

X={x1,x2,...,xn}X=\{x_1,x_2,...,x_n\} X={x1​,x2​,...,xn​}

therefore

cNB=arg max⁡c∈CP(cj)∏x∈XP(x∣c),X={x1,x2,...,xn}c_{NB}=\argmax_{c\in C}P(c_j)\prod_{x\in X}P(x|c),X=\{x_1,x_2,...,x_n\} cNB​=c∈Cargmax​P(cj​)x∈X∏​P(x∣c),X={x1​,x2​,...,xn​}

then for all words:

cNB=arg max⁡cj∈CP(cj)∏i∈positionsP(xi∣cj)(1)c_{NB}=\argmax_{c_j\in C}P(c_j)\prod_{i\in positions}P(x_i|c_j) \tag{1} cNB​=cj​∈Cargmax​P(cj​)i∈positions∏​P(xi​∣cj​)(1)

positionspositionspositions = all word positions in the test document

for (1)(1)(1),

Multiplying floating point numbers may cause underflow loss,
then based on,

log⁡(ab)=log⁡(a)+log⁡(b)\log(ab)=\log(a)+\log(b) log(ab)=log(a)+log(b)

then for (1)(1)(1),

cNB=arg max⁡cj∈CP(cj)∏i∈positionsP(xi∣cj)(1)c_{NB}=\argmax_{c_j\in C}P(c_j)\prod_{i\in positions}P(x_i|c_j)\tag{1} cNB​=cj​∈Cargmax​P(cj​)i∈positions∏​P(xi​∣cj​)(1)

=arg max⁡cj∈C[log⁡P(cj)+∑i∈positionslog⁡P(xi∣cj)](2)=\argmax_{c_j\in C}\Biggl[\log{P(c_j)}+\sum_{i\in positions}\log{P(x_i|c_j)}\Biggl] \tag{2} =cj​∈Cargmax​[logP(cj​)+i∈positions∑​logP(xi​∣cj​)](2)

  • For the maximum likelihood estimates P(cj)P(c_j)P(cj​):

P(cj)=doccount(C=cj)NdocP(c_j)=\frac{doccount(C=c_j)}{N_{doc}} P(cj​)=Ndoc​doccount(C=cj​)​

Get the frequencies of the class appear in the dataset.

  • For the Parameter estimation P(wi∣cj)P(w_i|c_j)P(wi​∣cj​):

P(wi∣cj)=count(wi,cj)∑w∈Vcount(w,cj)P(w_i|c_j)= \frac{count(w_i,c_j)}{\sum_{w \in V} count(w,c_j)} P(wi​∣cj​)=∑w∈V​count(w,cj​)count(wi​,cj​)​

(VVV is the vocabulary maintaining all the words used for classification in dataset we trained)

Get the frequencies of the word wiw_iwi​ appears within all word in the dataset with class cjc_jcj​.

Problem:

No training of some words will lead the result to 0 directly, which is improper.

Solution:

Laplace (add-1) Smoothing for Naive Bayes

P(wi∣cj)=count(wi,cj)+1∑w∈V(count(w,cj)+1)=count(wi,cj)+1(∑w∈Vcount(w,cj))+∣V∣P(w_i|c_j)= \frac{count(w_i,c_j)+1}{\sum_{w \in V} (count(w,c_j)+1)}=\frac{count(w_i,c_j)+1}{\biggl(\sum_{w \in V} count(w,c_j)\biggr)+|V|} P(wi​∣cj​)=∑w∈V​(count(w,cj​)+1)count(wi​,cj​)+1​=(∑w∈V​count(w,cj​))+∣V∣count(wi​,cj​)+1​

Problem:

For the Unknown word.

Solution:

Ignore them, remove them from the test document

Problem:

Deal with the stopwords(e.g., the, a)

Solution:

Sort the whole vocabulary by frequency in the training, call the top 10 or 50 words the stopwords list, and remove them from the dataset.
It’s more common to ignore stopwords lists and only use all the words.

The weighted square distance from the mean.

3.3 Sample Statistics

  • Assumptions:

    • The population is infinite (or very large).
    • The observations are independent.

  • Statistic itself is a random variable

3.3.1 Sample Mean

Xˉ=1n(X1+X2+...+Xn)\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}(X_1+X_2+...+X_n) Xˉ=n1​(X1​+X2​+...+Xn​)

3.3.2 Sample Variance and Standard Deviation

Sample Variance:

S=1n−1∑k=1n(Xk−Xˉ)2S=\frac{1}{n-1}\sum^n_{k=1}(X_k-\bar{X})^2 S=n−11​k=1∑n​(Xk​−Xˉ)2

Standard Deviation:

S=1n−1∑k=1n(Xk−Xˉ)2S=\sqrt{\frac{1}{n-1}\sum^n_{k=1}(X_k-\bar{X})^2} S=n−11​k=1∑n​(Xk​−Xˉ)2​

3.3.3 Other of Sample Statistics

  • order statistic: observation are ordered in size;
  • sample median:
    • nnn is odd: mid-value of the order statistic;
    • nnn is even: average of the two middle values;
  • sample range: Max - Min

3.3.4 Expected Value and Variance of Sample Mean

Sample Mean:

Xˉ=1n(X1+X2+...+Xn)\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}(X_1+X_2+...+X_n) Xˉ=n1​(X1​+X2​+...+Xn​)

It is also a Radom Variable.

The Expected value of Sample Mean:

μXˉ=E[Xˉ]=E[1n(X1+X2+...+Xn)]=μ\mu_{\bar{X}}=E[\bar{X}]=E\biggl[\frac{1}{n}(X_1+X_2+...+X_n)\biggr]=\mu μXˉ​=E[Xˉ]=E[n1​(X1​+X2​+...+Xn​)]=μ

The Variance of Sample Mean:

σXˉ2=Var[Xˉ]=σ2n\sigma_{\bar{X}}^2=Var[\bar{X}]=\frac{\sigma^2}{n} σXˉ2​=Var[Xˉ]=nσ2​

(n→+∞  ⟹  σXˉ2→0n\to +\infin \implies \sigma_{\bar{X}}^2 \to 0n→+∞⟹σXˉ2​→0)

[Proof]

Set:

S=x1+x2+...+xnnXˉ=SS=x_1+x_2+...+x_n\\n\bar{X}=S S=x1​+x2​+...+xn​nXˉ=S

Then:

Var[Xˉ]=E[Xˉ2]−μ2=1n2E[S2]−μ2=1n2E[(x1+x2+...+xn)2]−μ2=1n2E[∑i=1nxi2+∑i≠jxixj]−μ2=1n2[nE[xi2]+n(n−1)E(xixj)]−μ2=1n2[n(σ2+μ2)+n(n−1)μ2]−μ2=σ2nVar[\bar{X}]=E[\bar{X}^2]-\mu^2\\=\frac{1}{n^2}E[S^2]-\mu^2\\=\frac{1}{n^2}E[(x_1+x_2+...+x_n)^2]-\mu^2\\=\frac{1}{n^2}E\biggl[\sum_{i=1}^nx_i^2+\sum_{i\ne j}x_ix_j\biggr]-\mu^2\\=\frac{1}{n^2}\biggl[nE[x_i^2]+n(n-1)E(x_ix_j)\biggr]-\mu^2\\=\frac{1}{n^2}\biggl[n(\sigma^2+\mu^2)+n(n-1)\mu^2\biggr]-\mu^2\\=\frac{\sigma^2}{n} Var[Xˉ]=E[Xˉ2]−μ2=n21​E[S2]−μ2=n21​E[(x1​+x2​+...+xn​)2]−μ2=n21​E[i=1∑n​xi2​+i​=j∑​xi​xj​]−μ2=n21​[nE[xi2​]+n(n−1)E(xi​xj​)]−μ2=n21​[n(σ2+μ2)+n(n−1)μ2]−μ2=nσ2​

3.3.5 Markov Inequality and Chebyshev’s Inequality

Markov Inequality:

X≥0,ϵ>0X\ge 0,\epsilon \gt 0X≥0,ϵ>0

P(X≥ϵ)≤E[X]ϵP(X\ge \epsilon)\le \frac{E[X]}{\epsilon} P(X≥ϵ)≤ϵE[X]​

[Proof]

E[X]=∑x≥0xp(x)≥∑x≥ϵxp(x)≥ϵ∑x≥ϵp(x)=ϵP(X≥ϵ)E[X]=\sum_{x\ge 0}xp(x)\ge \sum_{x\ge \epsilon}xp(x)\ge \epsilon \sum_{x\ge \epsilon}p(x)=\epsilon P(X\ge \epsilon) E[X]=x≥0∑​xp(x)≥x≥ϵ∑​xp(x)≥ϵx≥ϵ∑​p(x)=ϵP(X≥ϵ)

Chebyshev’s Inequality:

P(∣X−μ∣≥ϵ)≤σ2ϵ2P(|X-\mu |\ge \epsilon)\le \frac{\sigma^2}{\epsilon^2} P(∣X−μ∣≥ϵ)≤ϵ2σ2​

[Proof]

P(∣X−μ∣≥ϵ)=P((X−μ)2≥ϵ2)≤E[(X−μ)2]ϵ2=σ2ϵ2P(|X-\mu |\ge \epsilon)=P((X-\mu )^2\ge \epsilon^2)\le \frac{E[(X-\mu )^2]}{\epsilon^2}=\frac{\sigma^2}{\epsilon^2}P(∣X−μ∣≥ϵ)=P((X−μ)2≥ϵ2)≤ϵ2E[(X−μ)2]​=ϵ2σ2​

3.3.6 Law of Large Number

According to the Chebyshev’s Inequality:

P(∣X−μ∣≥ϵ)≤σ2ϵ2P(|X-\mu |\ge \epsilon)\le \frac{\sigma^2}{\epsilon^2} P(∣X−μ∣≥ϵ)≤ϵ2σ2​

then, for any random variables:

P(∣X−μ∣≥ϵ)≥1−σXˉ2ϵ2=1−σ2nϵ2P(|X-\mu |\ge \epsilon)\ge 1-\frac{\sigma_{\bar{X}}^2}{\epsilon^2}=1-\frac{\sigma^2}{n\epsilon^2} P(∣X−μ∣≥ϵ)≥1−ϵ2σXˉ2​​=1−nϵ2σ2​

for n→+∞,  P(∣X−μ∣≥ϵ)=1,  ∀ϵ>0n\to +\infin,\; P(|X-\mu |\ge \epsilon)=1,\; \forall \epsilon \gt 0n→+∞,P(∣X−μ∣≥ϵ)=1,∀ϵ>0

Means the sample mean approximates the population mean for very large nnn.

3.3.7 General and Standard Normal

f(x)=12πσe−12σ2(x−μ)2f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}\sigma}e^{-\frac{1}{2\sigma^2}(x-\mu )^2} f(x)=2π​σ1​e−2σ21​(x−μ)2

XXX is general normal, X∼N(μ,σ2)X\sim N(\mu ,\sigma^2)X∼N(μ,σ2)

Properties:

  • E[X]=μE[X]=\muE[X]=μ
  • Var(X)=μ2Var(X)=\mu^2Var(X)=μ2
  • X−μσ∼N(0,1)\frac{X-\mu}{\sigma}\sim N(0,1)σX−μ​∼N(0,1)

when μ=0,σ=1\mu =0,\sigma=1μ=0,σ=1:

f(x)=12πe−12σ2x2f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{-\frac{1}{2\sigma^2}x^2} f(x)=2π​1​e−2σ21​x2

XXX is standard normal, X∼N(0,1)X\sim N(0,1)X∼N(0,1)

3.3.8 Central Limit Theorem

Sample Mean:

Xˉ=1n(X1+X2+...+Xn)\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}(X_1+X_2+...+X_n) Xˉ=n1​(X1​+X2​+...+Xn​)

The Expected value of Sample Mean:

μXˉ=E[Xˉ]=E[1n(X1+X2+...+Xn)]=μ\mu_{\bar{X}}=E[\bar{X}]=E\biggl[\frac{1}{n}(X_1+X_2+...+X_n)\biggr]=\mu μXˉ​=E[Xˉ]=E[n1​(X1​+X2​+...+Xn​)]=μ

The Variance of Sample Mean:

σXˉ2=Var[Xˉ]=σ2n\sigma_{\bar{X}}^2=Var[\bar{X}]=\frac{\sigma^2}{n} σXˉ2​=Var[Xˉ]=nσ2​

  • Xˉ\bar{X}Xˉ is approximately general normal (or satisfies normal distribution) for very large nnn.

  • X−μXˉσ=X−μσn\frac{X-\mu_{\bar{X}}}{\sigma}=\frac{X-\mu}{\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}}σX−μXˉ​​=n​σ​X−μ​ is approximately normal normal for very large nnn.

3.3.9 Confidence Interval Estimate

For the continuous random variable XXX, ∀x∈R\forall x \in \Bbb{R}∀x∈R

4.1.4 Vector Norm

Euclidean Norm of n-vector:

∥x∥=x12+x22+⋯+xn2=xTx\lVert x \rVert=\sqrt{x_1^2+x_2^2+\cdots + x_n^2}=\sqrt{x^Tx} ∥x∥=x12​+x22​+⋯+xn2​​=xTx​

Properties:

  • Homogeneity:

∥βx∥=∣β∣∥x∥\lVert \beta x \rVert = |\beta| \lVert x \rVert ∥βx∥=∣β∣∥x∥

  • Triangle Inequality:

∥x+y∥≤∥x∥+∥y∥\lVert x+y \rVert\le \lVert x \rVert+\lVert y \rVert ∥x+y∥≤∥x∥+∥y∥

  • Non-negativity:

∥x∥≥0\lVert x \rVert\ge 0 ∥x∥≥0

  • Definiteness:

∥x∥=0  ⟺  x=0\lVert x \rVert=0\iff x=0 ∥x∥=0⟺x=0

∥x−y∥=(x1−y1)2+(x2−y2)2+⋯+(xn−yn)2\lVert x-y \rVert=\sqrt{(x_1-y_1)^2+(x_2-y_2)^2+\cdots + (x_n-y_n)^2} ∥x−y∥=(x1​−y1​)2+(x2​−y2​)2+⋯+(xn​−yn​)2​

4.1.6 Vector Angle

Angle θ\thetaθ between two non-zero vector aaa and bbb:

cos⁡θ=aTb∥a∥⋅∥b∥\cos \theta = \frac{a^Tb}{\lVert a \rVert\cdot \lVert b \rVert} cosθ=∥a∥⋅∥b∥aTb​

  ⟺  aTb=cos⁡θ⋅∥a∥⋅∥b∥\iff a^Tb=\cos \theta \cdot {\lVert a \rVert\cdot \lVert b \rVert} ⟺aTb=cosθ⋅∥a∥⋅∥b∥

Properties:

  • θ=π2\theta = \frac{\pi}{2}θ=2π​: a⊥ba\bot ba⊥b;
  • θ=0\theta = 0θ=0: aaa and bbb are aligned, aTb=∥a∥⋅∥b∥a^Tb={\lVert a \rVert\cdot \lVert b \rVert}aTb=∥a∥⋅∥b∥;
  • θ=π\theta = \piθ=π: aaa and bbb are anti-aligned, aTb=−∥a∥⋅∥b∥a^Tb=-{\lVert a \rVert\cdot \lVert b \rVert}aTb=−∥a∥⋅∥b∥;
  • θ∈(0,π2)\theta \in (0,\frac{\pi}{2})θ∈(0,2π​): aaa and bbb make a acute angle, aTb>0a^Tb\gt 0aTb>0;
  • θ∈(π2,π)\theta \in (\frac{\pi}{2},\pi)θ∈(2π​,π): aaa and bbb make a obtuse angle, aTb<0a^Tb\lt 0aTb<0.

Proof:

LHS=cos⁡θ=cos⁡(α−β)LHS=\cos \theta=\cos (\alpha-\beta) LHS=cosθ=cos(α−β)

=cos⁡αcos⁡β+sin⁡αsin⁡β= \cos \alpha \cos \beta + \sin \alpha\sin \beta =cosαcosβ+sinαsinβ

=axbx∥a∥⋅∥b∥+ayby∥a∥⋅∥b∥= \frac{a_xb_x}{\lVert a \rVert\cdot \lVert b \rVert}+\frac{a_yb_y}{\lVert a \rVert\cdot \lVert b \rVert} =∥a∥⋅∥b∥ax​bx​​+∥a∥⋅∥b∥ay​by​​

=axbx+ayby∥a∥⋅∥b∥= \frac{a_xb_x+a_yb_y}{\lVert a \rVert\cdot \lVert b \rVert} =∥a∥⋅∥b∥ax​bx​+ay​by​​

=aTb∥a∥⋅∥b∥=RHS= \frac{a^Tb}{\lVert a \rVert\cdot \lVert b \rVert}=RHS =∥a∥⋅∥b∥aTb​=RHS

4.2 Clustering

NNN n-vector, x1,x2,⋯ ,xnx_1,x_2,\cdots, x_nx1​,x2​,⋯,xn​:
Cluster them into kkk clusters(groups),

Goal is to make vectors in the same cluster to be close to each other.

4.2.1 Clustering Objective

Group Assignment:
cic_ici​: the index of a group;
Assigned to vector xi,  xi∈Gcix_i,\; x_i\in G_{c_i}xi​,xi​∈Gci​​.

Group Representatives:
n-vectors z1,z2,⋯ ,zkz_1,z_2,\cdots,z_kz1​,z2​,⋯,zk​

Clustering Objective:

Jcluster=1N∑i=1N∥xi−zci∥2J^{cluster}=\frac{1}{N}\sum^N_{i=1}\lVert x_i-z_{c_i}\rVert^2 Jcluster=N1​i=1∑N​∥xi​−zci​​∥2

Smaller, the better

4.2.2 K-means Clustering Algorithm

Repeatedly alternate between updating the group assignments, and then updating the representatives, then JclusterJ^{cluster}Jcluster goes down.

Algorithm:
Given x1,x2,⋯ ,xNx_1,x_2,\cdots , x_Nx1​,x2​,⋯,xN​ N vectors, and initially z1,z2,⋯ ,zkz_1,z_2,\cdots , z_kz1​,z2​,⋯,zk​ k representatives which is randomly selected at begin;
Repeat:

  • Update group assignments: assign iii to GjG_jGj​, i=argminj′∥xi−zj′∥i= argmin_{j'}\lVert x_i-z_{j'}\rVerti=argminj′​∥xi​−zj′​∥, let xix_ixi​ assigned to the group associated with the nearest representative;
  • Update representatives: zj=1∣Gj∣∑i∈Gjxiz_j=\frac{1}{|G_j|}\sum_{i\in G_j}x_izj​=∣Gj​∣1​∑i∈Gj​​xi​, to be the mean of the vectors in group jjj.

Until group representative stop change.

StatQuest: K-means clustering

Rectangular array of numbers:

(135246)\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 & 5\\2& 4& 6 \end{pmatrix}(12​34​56​)

  • entries: the elements;
  • Mi,jM_{i,j}Mi,j​: entry at ithi^{th}ith row and jthj^{th}jth column;

ATA^TAT: Transpose of Matrices

(AT)i,j=Aj,i(A^T)_{i,j} = A_{j,i} (AT)i,j​=Aj,i​

(135246)T=(123456)\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 & 5\\2& 4& 6 \end{pmatrix}^T=\begin{pmatrix} 1&2\\3&4\\5&6 \end{pmatrix}(12​34​56​)T=⎝⎛​135​246​⎠⎞​

  • Subtract: Same size matrix

  • Scalar multiplication:

Properties:

α(A+B)=αA+αB\alpha(A+B) = \alpha A + \alpha B α(A+B)=αA+αB

(A+B)T=AT+BT(A+B)^T=A^T+B^T (A+B)T=AT+BT

matrix AAA of m×nm\times nm×n, n-vector xxx, y=Axy=Axy=Ax:

yi=Ai,1x1+Ai,2x2+⋯ ,Ai,nxny_i=A_{i,1}x_1+A_{i,2}x_2+\cdots, A_{i,n}x_n yi​=Ai,1​x1​+Ai,2​x2​+⋯,Ai,n​xn​

5 Calculus Basics

5.1 Functions

y=f(x)y = f(x) y=f(x)

yyy is a function of xxx, the value of x corresponds to one and only one value of yyy.

xxx: independent variable;
yyy: dependent variable.

5.1.1 Optimization of a Function

Optimization: Find a set of variables x1,x2,⋯ ,xnx_1,x_2,\cdots,x_nx1​,x2​,⋯,xn​ that maximize or minimize f(x1,x2,⋯ ,xn)f(x_1,x_2,\cdots,x_n)f(x1​,x2​,⋯,xn​).

5.2 Derivatives

Derivative of f(x)f(x)f(x):

  • The slope of tangent line (instantaneous rate of change) at (x,f(x))(x,f(x))(x,f(x));

Differentiation:

  • the process of calculating derivative of f(x)f(x)f(x);

dydx=f′(x)=lim⁡Δx→0f(x+Δx)−f(x)Δx\frac{dy}{dx}=f^\prime(x)=\lim_{\Delta x \to 0}\frac{f(x+\Delta x)-f(x)}{\Delta x} dxdy​=f′(x)=Δx→0lim​Δxf(x+Δx)−f(x)​

5.2.1 Useful Derivative Rules

Power Rule:

  • d(xp)dx=pxp−1\frac{d(x^p)}{dx}=px^{p-1} dxd(xp)​=pxp−1

Exponential Rule:

  • d(bx)dx=bxlnb\frac{d(b^x)}{dx}=b^x lnb dxd(bx)​=bxlnb

  • d(ex)dx=ex\frac{d(e^x)}{dx}=e^x dxd(ex)​=ex

Logarithm Rule:

  • d(logbx)dx=1xlnb\frac{d(log_bx)}{dx}=\frac{1}{x lnb} dxd(logb​x)​=xlnb1​

  • d(lnx)dx=1x\frac{d(lnx)}{dx}=\frac{1}{x} dxd(lnx)​=x1​

Derivatives for constants:

  • dCdx=0\frac{dC}{dx}=0 dxdC​=0

5.2.2 Properties of Derivatives

Constant:

  • d[cf(x)]dx=cd[f(x)]dx\frac{d[cf(x)]}{dx}=c\frac{d[f(x)]}{dx} dxd[cf(x)]​=cdxd[f(x)]​

Sum and Difference Rules:

  • d[f(x)±g(x)]dx=d[f(x)]dx±d[g(x)]dx\frac{d[f(x)\pm g(x)]}{dx}=\frac{d[f(x)]}{dx}\pm \frac{d[g(x)]}{dx} dxd[f(x)±g(x)]​=dxd[f(x)]​±dxd[g(x)]​

Product Rule:

  • [f(x)g(x)]′=f′(x)g(x)+f(x)g′(x)[f(x)g(x)]^\prime =f^\prime(x)g(x)+f(x)g^\prime(x) [f(x)g(x)]′=f′(x)g(x)+f(x)g′(x)

Quotient Rule:

  • [f(x)g(x)]′=f′(x)g(x)−f(x)g′(x)[g(x)]2,g(x)≠0\biggl[\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\biggr]^\prime=\frac{f^\prime(x)g(x)-f(x)g^\prime(x)}{[g(x)]^2},g(x)\ne 0 [g(x)f(x)​]′=[g(x)]2f′(x)g(x)−f(x)g′(x)​,g(x)​=0

Chain Rule:

  • [f(g(x))]′=f′(g(x))⋅g′(x)\big[f\big(g(x)\big)\big]^\prime=f^\prime\big(g(x)\big)\cdot g^\prime (x) [f(g(x))]′=f′(g(x))⋅g′(x)

5.2.3 Partial Derivatives

  • For a function with several variables;
  • Derivative with respect to one of those variables;
  • with others as constants;
  • Denoted as δfδx\frac{\delta f}{\delta x}δxδf​ or dfdx\frac{df}{dx}dxdf​.

5.2.4 Gradient

  • For f(x1,x2,⋯ ,xn)f(x_1,x_2,\cdots,x_n)f(x1​,x2​,⋯,xn​),
  • Gradient is the vector holding all partial derivatives:
  • ∇f=(δfδx1,δfδx2,⋯ ,δfδxn)\nabla f = (\frac{\delta f}{\delta x_1},\frac{\delta f}{\delta x_2},\cdots, \frac{\delta f}{\delta x_n})∇f=(δx1​δf​,δx2​δf​,⋯,δxn​δf​);
  • It points the direction of the greatest rate of change.

w=w0−ηdl(w)dww=w_0-\eta \frac{dl(w)}{dw} w=w0​−ηdwdl(w)​

  • Moving in the opposite direction of the gradient of the loss function.
  • η\etaη: the moving step length, to avoid pass the goal.

5.2.5 The Training of Machine Learning

Generative Classifier:

  • Calculus the probability of each object;
  • Run model for each one;
  • e.g. Naïve Bayes classifier.

Discriminative Classifier:

  • Distinguish one from another;

Input: x1,x2,⋯ ,xnx_1,x_2,\cdots,x_nx1​,x2​,⋯,xn​, the feature representation;
Output: y^\hat{y}y^​, the prediction, via p(y∣x)p(y|x)p(y∣x) function.
The object function to learn: cross-entropy loss, using gradient descent tor optimizing.

Linear Regression:

  • Input: feature x1,x2,⋯ ,xnx_1,x_2,\cdots,x_nx1​,x2​,⋯,xn​, and weight over feature θ1,θ2,⋯ ,θn\theta_1,\theta_2,\cdots,\theta_nθ1​,θ2​,⋯,θn​;
  • Output: y^=hθ(x)=f(θTx)\hat{y}=h_\theta(x)=f(\theta^Tx)y^​=hθ​(x)=f(θTx), where f(a)=af(a)=af(a)=a, which is linear.

In order to get from numbers to 0-to-1, need to use sigmoid or logistic function:

Sigmoid or Logistic Regression:

  • Input: feature x1,x2,⋯ ,xnx_1,x_2,\cdots,x_nx1​,x2​,⋯,xn​, and weight over feature θ1,θ2,⋯ ,θn\theta_1,\theta_2,\cdots,\theta_nθ1​,θ2​,⋯,θn​;
  • Output: y^=hθ(x)=f(θTx)\hat{y}=h_\theta(x)=f(\theta^Tx)y^​=hθ​(x)=f(θTx), where f(a)=11+exp(−a)f(a)=\frac{1}{1+exp(-a)}f(a)=1+exp(−a)1​, which is sigmoid or logistic.
  • Only fix to binary classification, not 3 or 4…

A recipe:

  1. Training Data: {xi,yi}i=1N\{x_i,y_i\}_{i=1}^N{xi​,yi​}i=1N​, where xxx is the feature and yyy is the label.
  2. Decision function: y^=fθ(xi)\hat{y}=f_\theta (x_i)y^​=fθ​(xi​), where fff is the sigmoid function;
  3. Loss function: l(y^,yi)∈Rl(\hat{y},y_i)\in \Bbb{R}l(y^​,yi​)∈R;
  4. The Goal: θ∗=argminθ∑i=1Nl(fθ(xi),yi)\theta^*=argmin_\theta \sum^N_{i=1}l(f_\theta (x_i),y_i)θ∗=argminθ​∑i=1N​l(fθ​(xi​),yi​);
  5. Training with SGD, small steps opposite the gradient: $$\theta{(t+1)}=\theta{(t)}-\eta_t \nabla l(f_\theta(x_i),y_i)$$

5.3 Integrals

Definite Integrals:

F(x)=∫axf(t)dtF(x)=\int^x_af(t)dt F(x)=∫ax​f(t)dt

  • f(x)f(x)f(x): integrand;
  • F(x)F(x)F(x): antiderivative of f(x)f(x)f(x).

Indefinite integrals:

∫f(x)dx=F(x)+C\int f(x)dx= F(x)+C ∫f(x)dx=F(x)+C

5.3.1 Properties of Integrals

Sum and Difference Rules:

∫[f(x)±g(x)]dx=∫f(x)dx±∫g(x)dx\int[f(x)\pm g(x)]dx=\int f(x)dx \pm \int g(x)dx ∫[f(x)±g(x)]dx=∫f(x)dx±∫g(x)dx

Power Rule:

∫updu={up+1p+1+C,p≠−1ln∣u∣+C,p=−1\int u^pdu=\begin{cases} \frac{u^{p+1}}{p+1}+C,&p\ne-1\\ ln|u|+C,&p=-1 \end{cases}∫updu={p+1up+1​+C,ln∣u∣+C,​p​=−1p=−1​

Exponential Rule:

∫eudu=eu+C\int e^udu=e^u+C ∫eudu=eu+C

Chain Rule:

6 Programming with R

6.1 R Basic

  • Created objects are held in memory;
  • The workspace (the collection of objects you currently have) is not saved on disk unless you tell R to do so;
  • Save: save.image();
  • Check the current working directory: getwd();
  • Save to a specific file and location: save.image("path")
  • List the objects in the current workspace: ls(), ls(pattern="x");
  • Remove onr or more objects: remove(x,x2);
  • Quit R: q();
  • Load the workspace: load("path");
  • Help:

  • Assignment operators:

    • <-: An arrow formed by a smaller than character and a hyphen without a space;
    • =: equal character;

  • Naming rules:

    • CANNOT contain ‘strange’ symbols like !, +, -, #;
    • A dot . and an underscore _ are allowed, also a name starting with a dot;
    • CAN contain a number but CANNOT start with a number;
    • Case sensitive, X and x are two different objects, as well as temp and temP.

  • Check packages currently attached in the system: search();

  • Check available library can be used in the system: library();

6.2 R Data types

6.2.1 Vectors

Vector is the core element of R, it includes scalars, characters, logical values, but not mixed.

Using c(...) to initialize:

Concatenate two vector into a new vector:

Starts at index 1 instead of 0!

ELements referencing:

  1. v[x]

  2. v[n:m]
    inclusively

    Accessing from 1 to n+1:v[1:(n+1)], instead ofv[1:n+1];

  3. v[c(a,b,c,...)]
    Accessing via data vector;

  4. v[-x]
    Ignore some elements;

  5. v[x<y]
    Accessing via boolean expression, TRUE for selected, FALSE for ignore;

  6. names()
    Give names to some elements, and accessing via names;

7 Data Analytics with R

7.1 Simulations

A simulation is an approximate imitation of the operation of a process or system.

7.1.1 Generate Random Numbers

  • rnorm(amount,μ,σ\text{amount},\mu,\sigmaamount,μ,σ): generate random Normal variates with a given mean and standard deviation;
    • generated continuously variables;
  • dnorm: evaluate the Normal probability density (with a given mean/SD) at a point (or vector of points);
  • pnorm: evaluate the cumulative distribution function for a Normal distribution.

7.1.2 Number Seed

A random seed is a number used to initialize a pseudorandom number generator (a starting point).

7.1.3 Simulating a Linear Model

y=β0+β1x+ϵ(β0=0.5,β1=2)y=\beta_0+\beta_1x+\epsilon(\beta_0=0.5,\beta_1=2) y=β0​+β1​x+ϵ(β0​=0.5,β1​=2)

ϵ∼N(0,22),x∼N(0,12)\epsilon\sim N(0,2^2), x\sim N(0,1^2) ϵ∼N(0,22),x∼N(0,12)

⇓\Downarrow ⇓

7.1.4 Random Sampling

The sample() function draws randomly from a specified set of (scalar) objects allowing you to sample from arbitrary distributions of numbers.

To sample a data frame:

sample the indices into an object rather than the elements of the object itself.

7.2 Monte Carlo Simulation

A method of estimating the value of an unknown quantity using the principles of inferential statistics

Inferential statistics:

Population: a set of examples

Sample: a proper subset of a population

Key fact: a random sample tends to exhibit the same properties as the population from which it is drawn

Confidence in our estimate depends upon two things

  • Size of sample;
  • Variance of sample.

Monte Carlo Principal:

  • In repeated independent tests with the same actual probability 𝑝 of a particular outcome in each test,the chance that the fraction of times that outcome occurs differs from p converges to zero as the number of trials goes to infinity

  • Intuition: if deviations from expected behaviour occur, these deviations are likely to be evened out by opposite deviations in the future.

  • Monte Carlo simulation is based on the law of large numbers.

  • The confidence of the estimation largely depends on the variance of samples.

  • The training method of Naïve Bayes can be seen as the Monte Carlo simulation.

  • Larger sample size may be helpful to draw unbiased results.

  • It is NOT a very effective method possibly allow 100% accuracy.

Poisson distribution

is often used to model rare events that are extremely unlikely to occur within a very short period of time or simultaneously (e.g. within 0.0001s).

describes the probability of a given number of events occurring in a fixed interval of time and/or space.

Exponential Distribution

used to model the time that elapses before an event occurs, e.g., the time between two events.

Exponential Distribution VS. Poisson Distribution
The inter-arrival times of events in a Poisson process with rate λ\lambdaλ is exponential and mean 1λ\frac{1}{\lambda}λ1​.

7.3 Regression and Time-series Analysis

7.3.1 Linear Regression

Introduction

Having bivariate data (xi,yi)(x_i,y_i)(xi​,yi​),

Goal: find a model of the relationship between xxx and yyy, and build a function y=f(x)y=f(x)y=f(x) fitting the data.

Assumptions: xix_ixi​ is not random, and yiy_iyi​ is function of xix_ixi​ plus some random noise.

xxx: the independent or predictor variable;
yyy: the dependent or response variable.

Implementation

Goal: find line y=β1x+β0y=\beta_1x+\beta_0y=β1​x+β0​ fitting the data.

Assumptions: Each yiy_iyi​ is predicted by xix_ixi​ up to some error ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​:

yi=β1xi+β0+ϵiy_i=\beta_1x_i+\beta_0+\epsilon_i yi​=β1​xi​+β0​+ϵi​

So the error is:

ϵi=yi−β1xi−β0\epsilon_i=y_i-\beta_1x_i-\beta_0 ϵi​=yi​−β1​xi​−β0​

Our goal is to find the β1\beta_1β1​ and β0\beta_0β0​ that minimize the sum of the squares of the errors which is:

S(β0,β1)=∑iϵi2=∑i(yi−β1xi−β0)S(\beta_0,\beta_1)=\sum_i \epsilon_i^2=\sum_i(y_i-\beta_1x_i-\beta_0) S(β0​,β1​)=i∑​ϵi2​=i∑​(yi​−β1​xi​−β0​)

Assume the found β1\beta_1β1​ and β0\beta_0β0​: β1^\hat{\beta_1}β1​^​ and β0^\hat{\beta_0}β0​^​:

Need to use calculus to find.

β1^=SxySxx,  β0^=yˉ−β1xˉ\hat{\beta_1} = \frac{S_{xy}}{S_{xx}},\; \hat{\beta_0}=\bar{y}-\beta_1\bar{x} β1​^​=Sxx​Sxy​​,β0​^​=yˉ​−β1​xˉ

where:

xˉ=1n∑ixi,  yˉ=1n∑iyi\bar{x}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_ix_i,\; \bar{y}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_iy_i xˉ=n1​i∑​xi​,yˉ​=n1​i∑​yi​

Sxx=1n−1∑i(xi−xˉ)2   : Sample VarianceS_{xx}=\frac{1}{n-1}\sum_i(x_i-\bar{x})^2\; \text{ : Sample Variance} Sxx​=n−11​i∑​(xi​−xˉ)2 : Sample Variance

Sxy=1n−1∑i(xi−xˉ)(yi−yˉ)   : Sample Covariance of x and yS_{xy}=\frac{1}{n-1}\sum_i(x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})\; \text{ : Sample Covariance of $x$ and $y$} Sxy​=n−11​i∑​(xi​−xˉ)(yi​−yˉ​) : Sample Covariance of x and y

Or simply:

Sxx=∑xi2−1n(∑xi)2S_{xx} = \sum x_i^2-\frac{1}{n}(\sum x_i)^2 Sxx​=∑xi2​−n1​(∑xi​)2

Sxy=∑xiyi−1n(∑xi)(∑yi)S_{xy} = \sum x_iy_i-\frac{1}{n}(\sum x_i)(\sum y_i) Sxy​=∑xi​yi​−n1​(∑xi​)(∑yi​)

Note

Linear Regression is not only fit in the line, can be in parabola.

Simple Linear Regression is fit a line to bivariate data.

Residuals

The error ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​ is called the residual, which is random noise or measurement error.

Homoscedasticity and Heteroscedasticity

Homoscedasticity: the residuals ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​ have the same variance for all iii, means data points should hover near the regression line more evenly.

Heteroscedasticity: the residuals ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​ have the different variance for all iii, means data points would not hover near the regression line more evenly.

Linear Regression for Multivariate

multivariate data: (x1,x2,...,xi,yi)(x_1,x_2,...,x_i,y_i)(x1​,x2​,...,xi​,yi​)

The fit line is y=β0+β1x1+β2x2+...+βixiy=\beta_0+\beta_1x_1+\beta_2x_2+...+\beta_ix_iy=β0​+β1​x1​+β2​x2​+...+βi​xi​

So,

S(β1,β2,...,βi)=∑i(β0+β1x1+β2x2+...+βixi−yi)2S(\beta_1,\beta_2,...,\beta_i)=\sum_i(\beta_0+\beta_1x_1+\beta_2x_2+...+\beta_ix_i-y_i)^2 S(β1​,β2​,...,βi​)=i∑​(β0​+β1​x1​+β2​x2​+...+βi​xi​−yi​)2

7.3.2 Polynomial Regression

Linear Regression’s Linear means the exponent of βi\beta_iβi​ is 1;
Polynomial Regression’s Polynomial means the exponent of βi\beta_iβi​ can be greater than 1.

For parabola:

The fit curve is y=β0+β1x+β2x2y=\beta_0+\beta_1x+\beta_2x^2y=β0​+β1​x+β2​x2

So,

S(β1,β2,β3)=∑i(β0+β1x1+β2x22−yi)2S(\beta_1,\beta_2,\beta_3)=\sum_i(\beta_0+\beta_1x_1+\beta_2x_2^2-y_i)^2 S(β1​,β2​,β3​)=i∑​(β0​+β1​x1​+β2​x22​−yi​)2

7.3.3 Fit Measurement

For

y=(y1,y2,...,yn)y=(y_1,y_2,...,y_n) y=(y1​,y2​,...,yn​)

h^=(y1^,y2^,...,yn^)\hat{h}=(\hat{y_1},\hat{y_2},...,\hat{y_n}) h^=(y1​^​,y2​^​,...,yn​^​)

Total Sum of Squares (TSS):

∑i(yi−yˉ)2   : variance\sum_i(y_i-\bar{y})^2\; \text{ : variance} i∑​(yi​−yˉ​)2 : variance

Residual Sum of Squares (RSS):

∑i(yi−yi^)2   : real - predicted\sum_i(y_i-\hat{y_i})^2\; \text{ : real - predicted} i∑​(yi​−yi​^​)2 : real - predicted

The goodness of fit:

R2=1−RSSTSSR^2=1-\frac{RSS}{TSS} R2=1−TSSRSS​

With larger variance, more complicated.

Overfitting:

More complex model, better fitness;
Tradeoff between goodness of fit and complexity.
